But perhaps they will move Arrow to Tuesday at 10 PM for Crossover week
They can't do that, the CW only has the 8pm to 10pm airspace.

Live+3 ratings don't really matter. The CW sells most of its commercials on C3 and C7 ratings, so Arrow is certainly being evaluated based on those, as well as other metrics pertaining to revenue.
Also if you rank the CW shows by L+SD ratings and them rank them by L+3 ratings the order is pretty much the same.

Exactly. It's just like how last year the AoS producers were spinning the move to 10pm as a good thing even though it clearly was not.
It's because the CW shows *are* cheap.
18-49 demographic ratings. C3 and C7 ratings are the most relevant but also rarely released to the public, so Live + Same Day is the next best.
So Live+7 total viewers, restricted to ABC comedies. Not a metric that matters to broadcast networks.

Riverdale has a better chance of standing up to shows like This is Us and the Shonda Rhimes block.

now they are gonna compete with Arrow
Gotham airs at 8, Arrow at 9; they're not in direct competition.

After Flash, assuming LoT has another 16-17 episode season.

[Here:](http://www.hollywoodreporter.com/amp/live-feed/abc-renews-agents-shield-1002925)
Sources tell The Hollywood Reporter that the show starring Clark Gregg and Ming Na has been working to reduce costs for its fifth season, with ABC looking to lower the drama's budget on the ABC Studios-produced series.
They're down from a 0.57 to a 0.51, but okay.

Two months ago it was up 150% for live +7 DVR.
TIL an 150% increase is tripling. [A month ago it increased 88% from L+SD to L+7](http://tvbythenumbers.zap2it.com/dvr-ratings/week-31-broadcast-live-7-ratings-april-17-23-2017/), which put it at another 1.5 in L+7. Currently it's doing around a 0.7 in L+SD; 1.5 is not three times 0.7.
Considering if you aren't a Neilsen family, your live viewing isn't even monitored, and streaming services force commercials on you, I don't think you are fully understanding exactly what C3 and C7 is actually measuring comparably to that of +3 and +7.
Neither Live+3 or C3 includes streaming views, those are measured separately and the numbers are not released to the public. Live+3 measures the number of people who watched the show live, DVRed, or On-Demand within 3 days; C3 measures the number of people who watched the commercials live, DVRed, or On-Demand within 3 days. Not unexpectedly C3 tends to a lot lower than Live+3, since most DVR viewers fast-forward commercials. (This all applies to Live+7 and C7 similarly.)
The AoS doomsayers have been saying the show was going to get cancelled every single season and it has not. In fact, it's gotten better and more people are watching it than before.
Anyone saying AoS was likely to get cancelled in its first few seasons wasn't doing so based on actual data. AoS ratings (relative to the rest of ABC) were quite good in S1 but have declined every season since then, to the point where they were near the bottom this season which is why people were concerned. And it has been reported that AoS had to cut its budget for S5, a clear sign that it was not performing as well as it used to and was in fact close to cancellation.

AoS triples its ratings at +7 viewing.
You keep repeating this, but it's not correct; AoS is not pulling 2.1s in Live+7.
Additionally networks get paid for C3 and C7 numbers, not Live+3 and Live+7. How many people DVRing AoS do you think actually watch the commercials?

based on no information.

WRITING.TITLE: Quantico Renewed For Season 3 By ABC

WRITING.TEXT: Being a lead on one of the most-watched shows on television makes him a star. Whether or not you personally find the show funny is completely irrelevant.

Being fearless may be a prerequisite to being a food descender but by itself doesn't make you one. Perhaps Quintana has improved but I from what I remember he would often take suboptimal lines through corners (including taking a terrible line into a corner on a descent in the 2014 Vuelta and crashing out as a result).
Physics obviously works against him because of his size, but from what I've seen he's not a particularly skilled descender either (by pro standards, obviously).
It looks no hillier than the 'flat' ITT in last year's Tour where Dumoulin beat Quintana by 3:08. Granted Dumoulin was training specifically for TTs rather than GC last year, but still.

Gotham has already faced TBBT and held up fine.
Orville looks to be targeting a different demographic than TIU so that may not be as big of a problem as it first appears.
Ratings are more for selling commercials than determining a show's total fanbase. And networks have access to mare data than just linear ratings.
to good?

Don't you have to already have a cable subscription for the streaming service to be free?
They're free to stream without a cable subscription, but for some shows you can't watch new episodes until a week after they aired unless you have a cable subscription.
Gotham held up well on Mondays against Monday Night Football, The Voice, and Dancing With The Stars; I don't see the Thursday competition as that much stronger that Gotham would get crushed.
Why?
Gotham already competed with Football and two huge reality shows on Mondays.

this show has a largely male audience and is now up against football.
This show was already up against football.

but their best performing scripted show?
Their best performing scripted show is Empire.

24 episodes for such a "dumb" show is just too much.
It had 23 episodes in both seasons combined.
Fox and FX may be owned by the same parent company but they're separate entities with different management.

This is currently the only X-Men show on Fox.
[MRW people want distance shown in km](http://i.imgur.com/6GEIUBw.jpg)

They had to cut the show's budget to get it renewed for S5, that alone shows that it wasn't that far from cancellation.
As for its timeslot, it wasn't a megaflop like the last few shows ABC aired in the Tuesday 10pm timelot but it still got crushed by the timeslot competition on NBC and CBS.

Variety says "theres speculation that the show could be a midseason entry next season" so I gues we'll have to wait and see what actually happens. If the syndication deal is still ongoing I could even see Elementary going to Saturdays.
Code Black getting renewed is not that surprising to me. It seems like the perfect schedule spackle: it's ratings last season were weak but really not that terrible, it's not very serialized (as far as I know) so it shouldn't suffer as heavily from an extended hiatus and/or getting moved around, and CBS presumably has some stake in the back-end what with it being a co-production.

It's not an ABC show. It is made by 20th Century Fox and ABC buys it from them. Since ABC doesn't own it, they don't get any syndication money or streaming money.
Yeah this is hugely important. As TV revenue continues to shift from first-run ad sales towards streaming and other back-end sources, networks are favoring in-house productions more than ever; expensive shows from outside studios have to perform very well to survive these days. CBS just cancelled Two Broke Girls for the same reason ABC cancelled LMS: it was from an outside studio and cast contracts were up for renewal meaning an increase in price, so it didn't make financial sense for the network despite the ratings being pretty good in a vacuum (and TGB had better ratings than LMS). Meanwhile at NBC, Blindspot and Timeless only got renewals after the producing studios (WB and Sony respectively) gave up major monetary concessions.

Isn't he contracted to Disney like, forever though?
LMS was produced by Fox so I highly doubt he's contracted to Disney.

'The Brave' sounds a lot more generic, but on the other hand I can definitely understand why they didn't want to go with 'For God and Country'. Overall I'd say it's probably an improvement from a business standpoint.

He specifically said thanks to the Flash finale, crossovers will be easier.
He didn't say that; go listen to it again.
['This Is Us' to air after Super Bowl](http://deadline.com/2017/05/this-is-us-to-super-bowl-christmas-episode-thursday-preemptions-1202093177/)
Okay? "Multiverse shit" is a prerequisite for any Flash-Supergirl crossovers, that says nothing about any merging or anything like that.
He said there would be more crossovers in the future, but didn't go into any more detail than that.

I don't recall reading that the deal was just for 5 seasons and syndication deals are often for the entire run of the show, so it's quite possible that WGN is still obligated to buy more episodes of Elementary if they're produced. Also the articles about Elementary's renewal mention the syndication deal as if it's still ongoing.
If the syndication deal is finished then it's hard to see why CBS would renew Elementary as spackle before Code Black or Criminal Minds: Beyond Borders. On the other hand if the syndication deal is still ongoing then I agree it's odd that it took so long for the renewal.

I am positive he talked about the Flash finale having big impacts on Supergirl
He didn't; go back and listen to the podcast again. It was slightly ambiguous but in context still pretty clear that he was talking about the *Supergirl* finale affecting Supergirl, not the Flash finale affecting Supergirl. He also mentioned that there would be more crossovers in the future, but said nothing about anything changing on the shows to make that easier.
People on reddit were so set on there being a merging of Earth-1 and Earth-S that they would ignore evidence to the contrary and misinterpret stuff like Kevin Smith's comments to support their opinion. Some were still convinced that it would happen months after the EPs straight-up said that it wasn't.

He teased a Crisis event last year for Supergirl and Flash's finale, an event that would make "crossing over the shows way more easier", something huge on Flash that would have big repercussions on Supergirl and its connection to the other shows.
To be fair, he didn't actually say that. He talked about the Supergirl finale having big effects on Supergirl, then people on reddit misinterpreted it because they were convinced there was going to be a Crisis or something similar and were willfully ignoring all evidence to the contrary.
Any fan poll you heard about had nothing to do with Timeless's uncancellation.
Everything is an emotional rollercoaster to Kevin Smith, i wouldn't read too much into this.

I agree that attributing the deaths from the nuke to Felicity's kill count is not accurate. However I think it is fair to attribute the deaths from the Undertaking (503 people) to Malcolm, which should put his kill count well above Oliver's.
*When the sun goes down the tide goes out...*
Colonel Flagg on MASH.
I feel like a lot of younger people are somehow unaware that broadcast networks are free to watch over the air and instead think that cable/satellite or streaming are the only ways to watch TV.

Nielsen ratings are still the standard metric for pricing the sale of commercials on networks' linear broadcasts. That says nothing about if/how networks are looking at other sources of revenue such as streaming (which they absolutely are doing).

Aside from the few EPs that work on multiple shows (and have done so since the inception of the shows) there has been very little transfer of writers between the shows. If you don't believe me go and look up the writing credits for each episode of all the shows.
No that's quite high (and has proven a very costly mistake for WGN America).

Syndication must be KILLING it.
Supposedly the syndication deal plus SVOD and whatnot brings in $3 million an episode, which would explain why CBS is keeping it around even with terrible ratings.
Now the reruns themselves have tanked in ratings, but that's WGN America's problem and not CBS's.
I guess WGN America hasn't been able to get out of its syndication deal yet.

Yeah Mom was at 9, and would often get higher ratings than TGI despite not having the TBBT lead-in. When they recently replaced TGI with TBBT repeats on Thurdays, the repeats rated better than TGI and Mom's ratings went up as well.
Its ratings were heavily inflated from airing after The Big Bang Theory. When they moved it to Mondays for 2 or 3 weeks it got worse ratings than all of their other comedies.

If only NBC had done the same for Constantine...
If only WB had agreed to give NBC most of the show's profits the way Sony reportedly did for Timeless... (although Constantine's ratings were arguably worse so it probably wouldn't have mattered).
As for Hannibal, NBC gave it three seasons despite it never having good ratings.

It seems like that's where the bulk of the viewers are.
And you think networks don't know that? Streaming rights are a major factor in network-studio negotiations these days.
The issue isn't just raw total viewership numbers but translating that viewership into revenue.

Is there a reason they can't just take online viewing more into consideration?
What makes you think they're not?
